content: The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" emphasizes the importance of preventive medicine in reducing healthcare costs and improving public health. It highlights the need for more public health professionals and increased focus on preventive methods to address chronic conditions. The Act also recognizes the decline in preventive medicine residency programs and the importance of a strong preventive medicine workforce. The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" promotes preventive medicine to reduce healthcare costs and improve public health. It allows the Secretary of Health and Human Services to pay up to $20,000 of medical education loans for eligible preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification in preventive medicine between fiscal years 2008-2012. Eligible physicians must apply for this payment by submitting an application containing required information. The "Wellness and Prevention Act of 2007" authorizes appropriations for the payment of medical education loans for preventive medicine physicians who receive board certification in preventive medicine at a school of medicine. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is responsible for this program, with funding allocated for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. SEC. 4. WELLNESS PROGRAM EMPLOYER CREDIT. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for a Wellness Program Employer Credit. The Wellness Program Employer Credit allows eligible employers to receive a tax credit of 25% of expenses incurred to develop and implement a qualified wellness program. The credit is capped at $200 per qualified employee. Eligible employers must maintain accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and programs. A qualified wellness program is defined as a program that meets specific criteria set forth in the legislation. A qualified wellness program for eligible employers must keep accurate records of employee participation in preventive services and programs. The program includes health risk assessments, offers recommended preventive services, and provides counseling sessions and seminars. The wellness program for eligible employers must offer at least 2 preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force annually, provide counseling sessions and seminars on various health topics, and have at least 50% of full-time employees as qualified participants. The eligible employer's wellness program must include at least 2 preventive services annually, counseling sessions, and seminars on health topics. Qualified employees are full-time employees who participate in the wellness program and undergo a health risk assessment. Qualified participants must engage in 2 annual preventive services and have a health risk assessment conducted by the employer. The section discusses the requirements for a qualified wellness program, including conducting a health risk assessment for eligible employees. The provision does not apply after December 31, 2012. Conforming amendments are made to Section 38(b) and the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of the tax code. The section introduces a new wellness program participant credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, applicable for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The section introduces a new wellness program participant credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, applicable for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. A qualified employee can receive a $200 tax credit if they are a full-time employee participating in the employer's wellness program. A qualified participant must engage in at least 2 annual preventive services and undergo a health risk assessment. The new wellness program participant credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 offers a $200 tax credit to qualified employees who participate in the employer's wellness program. The program must include health risk assessments, preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, and annual counseling sessions. The wellness program must conduct health risk assessments, offer preventive services recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force, provide annual counseling sessions and seminars on various health topics, and have at least 50% of eligible full-time employees participating. The eligible employer must develop and implement a qualified wellness program, keep accurate records of employee participation in preventive services, and have at least 50% of full-time employees participating. This section does not apply after December 31, 2012. The amendment under Sec. 25E introduces a wellness program participant credit, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007.
